contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox nrhp | name = U.S. Post Office, Customhouse, and Courthouse | nrhp_type = | image = HI-Honolulu 1922 Ref.jpg | caption = Building in 1931 | location= 335 Merchant Sreet, [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] | lat_degrees = 21 | lat_minutes = 18 | lat_seconds = 22 | lat_direction = N | long_degrees = 157 | long_minutes = 51 | long_seconds = 38 | long_direction = W | coord_display = inline,title | locmapin = Hawaii | built = 1921 | architect = York & Sawyer | architecture = [[Mission/Spanish Revival architecture|Mission/Spanish Revival]] | added = January 27, 1975 | area = {{convert|2.8|acre}} | governing_body = [[Hawaii|State of Hawaii]] | refnum = 75000620<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }} The '''King David Kalakaua Building''' in [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] is a government building formerly known as the '''U.S. Post Office, Customhouse, and Courthouse'''. It was the official seat of administration in the [[Territory of Hawaii]] and state of [[Hawaii]] for the [[United States]] [[Federal government of the United States|federal government]]. ==Federal building== The building was designed in 1918 and built from 1921 to 1922 in [[Mission/Spanish Revival architecture]]. An addition was added in 1929, and opened in 1931.<ref name="focus">{{cite web |title= U.S. Post Office, Customhouse, and Courthouse nomination form |author= Randall J. Biallas and Gerron S. Hite |work= National Register of Historic Places |date= May 22, 1973 |publisher= U.S. National Park Service |url= http://pdfhost.focus.nps.gov/docs/NRHP/Text/75000620.pdf |accessdate= October 21, 2010 }}</ref> Among other functions, it held courtrooms and offices for the [[United States District Court for the District of Hawaii]]. It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] (NRHP) on January 27, 1975, under the former name as site 75000620. In 1978 it was also included as a [[contributing property]] in the NRHP listing of the [[Hawaii Capital Historic District]].<ref name=nris/><ref>{{cite web |title= Hawaii Capital Historic District nomination form |author= Dale M. Lanzone and Gary Cummins |work= National Register of Historic Places |date= Spring 1976 |publisher= U.S. National Park Service |url= http://pdfhost.focus.nps.gov/docs/NRHP/Text/78001020.pdf |accessdate= October 11, 2010 }}</ref> ==State building== In December 2003, the federal government sold most of the building to the state of Hawaii for [[US Dollar|US$]]32.5 million, upon which the building was renamed in honor of [[Kalākaua|King David Kalākaua]] — last king of the Hawaiian monarchy. All federal agencies and departments moved their offices years earlier to the [[Prince Kuhio Federal Building]] near [[Honolulu Harbor]], except for a small section that retains a post office.<ref>{{cite news |title= Old post office assumes new role |newspaper= [[Honolulu Advertiser]] |date= December 30, 2003 |author= Gordon Y.K. Pang |url= http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2003/Dec/30/ln/ln29a.html |accessdate= April 2, 2011 }}</ref> The building holds offices of the Hawaii state Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. It is located at 335 Merchant Street.<ref>{{cite web |title= Directory of Services |publisher= Hawaii state Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs |date= January 2010 |url= http://hawaii.gov/dcca/dcca_directory_of_services.pdf |accessdate= October 11, 2010 }}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite web |title= U.S. Post Office, Court House, and Custom House; Honolulu, Hawaii |work= History of the Federal Judiciary |publisher= US Federal Judicial Center |url= http://www.fjc.gov/history/courthouses.nsf/getcourthouse?OpenAgent&chid=520F8D654A5B17038525718B005AE5D8 |accessdate= April 2, 2011 }} {{National Register of Historic Places}} [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Hawaii]] [[Category:Government buildings completed in 1922]] [[Category:Post office buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Hawaii]] [[Category:Government buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Hawaii]] [[Category:Courthouses in Hawaii]] [[Category:Post office buildings in Hawaii]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Honolulu, Hawaii]] [[Category:Mission Revival architecture in Hawaii]] [[Category:Spanish Colonial Revival architecture in Hawaii]] [[Category:Mediterranean Revival style architecture in Hawaii]] [[Category:Custom houses in the United States]]
